transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by reviewing your homework from the previous session. How did you find practicing self-compassionate reframing and assertive communication, particularly in work situations?

Patient: It was challenging, but I did notice some small improvements. I had a situation at work where a colleague asked me to take on an additional project, even though I was already overwhelmed with my current workload. Normally, I would have just said yes, but I tried to use assertive communication to explain that I couldn't take on anything else at the moment.

Therapist: That's a great example of using assertive communication to set boundaries. How did it feel to do that?

Patient: It was uncomfortable at first, because I'm so used to just saying yes and taking on more than I can handle. But afterwards, I felt a sense of relief, like I was taking care of myself by not overextending.

Therapist: That's a really important insight. By setting boundaries, you're actually practicing self-care and self-compassion. It's okay to prioritize your own needs and well-being, even in a work context. Did you face any challenges with the self-compassionate reframing?

Patient: I did. There were moments where I caught myself falling into old patterns of self-criticism, especially when I made a mistake or didn't meet my own high expectations. It's hard to break that habit of being so hard on myself.

Therapist: I completely understand. Self-criticism can be a deeply ingrained pattern, and it takes practice to shift into a more self-compassionate mindset. Remember, self-compassion is about treating yourself with the same kindness and understanding that you would extend to a good friend. When you notice those self-critical thoughts arising, try to pause and ask yourself, "What would I say to a friend in this situation?" 

Patient: That's a helpful reframe. I'll try to keep that in mind. I also wanted to mention that I've been using the coping cards we created, and I've found them really helpful. Just having those reminders and affirmations on hand has been a source of support.

Therapist: I'm so glad to hear that the coping cards have been helpful for you. They can be a powerful tool for reinforcing the new, adaptive thoughts and beliefs that we've been working on in therapy. As we move towards the end of our sessions together, it's important that you have these kinds of resources to support you in continuing this work independently.

Patient: That makes sense. I know that I need to keep practicing these skills even after our sessions end. It's comforting to know that I'll have the coping cards and other tools to fall back on.

Therapist: Absolutely. And speaking of continuing this work independently, I'd like to introduce a new concept called "becoming your own therapist." The idea is that you can apply the CBT principles and techniques that we've been working on in therapy to your own thoughts and experiences, even when you're not in a session with me. It's about developing the skills to be your own compassionate and rational guide.

Patient: That sounds empowering, but also a bit daunting. How do I go about becoming my own therapist?

Therapist: It's a process, and it starts with practicing the skills we've been working on consistently, both in and out of session. One way to do this is through meta-thought records, where you apply the thought record process to your own experiences with CBT. For example, if you notice yourself feeling anxious about using your CBT skills independently, you could do a thought record on that experience.

Patient: I think I understand. So it's like taking a step back and applying the CBT lens to my own thoughts and feelings about the therapy process itself.

Therapist: Exactly. It's a way of reinforcing your understanding of the CBT principles and building confidence in your ability to apply them independently. We can practice a meta-thought record together in session, and then you can try doing one on your own as homework.

Patient: That sounds good. I'm willing to give it a try. I know that I need to keep practicing these skills if I want to maintain the progress I've made.

Therapist: That's a great attitude to have. And remember, progress isn't always linear. There may be times when you struggle or face setbacks, and that's okay. The important thing is that you keep coming back to these skills and using them to support yourself.

Patient: I appreciate that reminder. It's easy to get discouraged when things don't go perfectly, but I'm trying to be more patient with myself.

Therapist: That's wonderful to hear. Let's practice a meta-thought record together now. Can you think of a recent experience where you had thoughts or feelings about the therapy process that we could explore?
